results.title: Trout country
results.brief_description: Trout fishing in the rivers and lakes of Tasmania. Shows the breeding grounds and the work of the Inland Fisheries Commission in studying the habits of the trout. Explains the five ways to angle trout - dry fly casting, wet fly fishing, spinning, natural bait from boat or shore, and trawling from a boat. Shows the famous Shannon Rise.

results.title: Troubled minds: the lithium revolution [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Dennis K. Smith, John Lewis, Film Australia and Omar Khayam Films
results.brief_description: Another first for Australian medical science is revealed in this fascinating documentary about Dr John Cade. Cade was a POW in Changi during World War II and during his time there he made the link between mental illness and body chemistry. At the time there were no other treatments for the mentally ill other than shock treatment, lobotomy and institutionalisation. With his wife and two young sons (who grew up in the grounds of a hospital), Cade’s research done whilst a doctor in residence, paved the way for the current treatment of bi-polar disorder and for chemical treatment of the mentally ill. The naturally occurring salt ‘lithium’ he worked with meant that the pharmaceutical companies were initially resistant to embrace his findings but those who followed up on his initial research and doctors who pursued the use of the salts, have resulted the de-institutionalisation of many people the world over and a revolution in the treatment of the mentally ill. A mixture of re-creations of the era, original historical footage and of contemporary interviews, this film serves as an interesting historical account as well as an educational resource. A Film Australia National Interest Program, developed with the assistance of Film Victoria and produced in association with SBS Independent.

results.title: Trouble with the law
results.brief_description:
Episode of series “Searching for values: a film anthology”
Edited from the feature film ‘Pursuit of happiness’, this extract shows how the legal process and justice are not always synonymous. A college student involved in a car accident rejects the standards by which the court finds him guilty and decides that justice has not been served.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Trouble shooting your car
results.brief_description: What a driver should do to locate and correct minor car troubles; how to follow an orderly and step-by-step procedure in checking why a car won’t start; and how to recognise symptoms of impending trouble.

results.title: Trouble in utopia
results.creator_credit: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Shock of the New Series”.
Part 4 of an 8-part series which presents a social history of the impact and development of the visual arts in the 20th century, by art critic and writer Robert Hughes. In each episode, Hughes examines the forces which monitored the directions painting, architecture and photography took from the late 1800’s to the present. In this episode the concept of ‘ideal modernity’ in the sphere of 20th century architecture is explored. Examines the result of attempts by architects to create an ideal society which arose out of a desire to remake the world.

results.title: Trouble for insects
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An entertaining film dedicated to “everyone who tries to make a garden - or even sleep in a garden”. The film is an account of some of the work being done by the Entomological Branch of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in their battle against insect pests.

results.title: Trouble : Responses to physical and emotional abuse
results.brief_description: Animated Norwegian production aimed at preventing sexual abuse in young children. The documentary begins with notions of uncomplicated ‘trouble’, such as being scared of a dog or not cleaning your room. There is a bigger item on the agenda, sexual abuse, and the documentary moves onto the area in an open and frank way. There is a case study presented of a young girl who is sexually abused by her uncle. She describes what happens and how she feels. The solution to her trouble is telling someone, which is the message the film portrays- that telling someone will drive the trouble away. The documentary is confronting in a way which is appropriate to the subject matter and perhaps necessary for instructing children about abuse. A leaflet accompanies the video. No other production detail available.

results.title: Tropical region
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “African Continent”
Shows geographic regions; population distribution, cultural influences, primary agricultural and natural resources, and emergence and development of the tropical region of Africa. Show four major regions: coastal lowlands, Congo Basin, Eastern Highlands, and Sudan, their climates, products and habitants, and the water power and mineral resources available but undeveloped.

results.title: Tropical north
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Life and work in the tropical areas of northern Queensland. Dense jungle provides a spectacle for the tourist and a challenge for the settler. Shows industries such as sugar-growing and timber-cutting, and the thriving city of Cairns. Commentator: Richard Davies

results.title: Tropical mountain island (Java)
results.creator_credit: Victor Jurgens and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description: Java is a tropical land, its fertility constantly replenished by volcanic ash. We board a train in a bustling seaport on the coastal plain and proceed gradually up the mountain slopes, stopping frequently to observe the people at work. As the train climbs, the climatic conditions and the crops change. Java produces great wealth in oil, rubber, teak, and quinine, as well as crops of tea, rice, sisal, kapok.
